content.description: A steep lie back gets your attention just off the belay; this is most likely the crux of the climb.  The climb protects well, but can be a little pumpy at the start; so move quickly to avoid landing on your belayer.
content.protection: Small to three inch camalots will do the trick.  The large pine tree on top of the buttress works well for an anchor, but can be full of sap; consider building an anchor just past the tree.
content.location: This is a large obvious flake that runs right through the center of the Lower Bulge Buttress.  It is 165 feet to the top and can also be a good first pitch to get to the start of Super Pooper, The Step or The Flakes.

climbs.name: Slapstick
climbs.fa: Dave Mayville and Bob Gaines, May 1999

content.description:
Although Tahquitz is known for it's multi-pitch goodness there happens to be a number of quality single pitch routes scattered across it's various faces and this is one such climb.

Balance and slap your way up the pronounced arÃªte as you encounter a definite crux down low and then hang on for the ride on this engaging, in-your-face testpiece.
content.location:
Between Le Toit Direct and

Standup Flake

.

content.description:
Lieback a tricky left-facing flake, clipping a fixed pin near it's end, before breaking out onto interesting steep slab that works up and left to join

Standup Flake

, which is taken to anchors atop Slapstick. The crux is found between the first two bolts, but the lieback at the start is off-balance and no giveaway and the upper face is fairly continuous as well.

This route finishes at a huge pine tree but most now stop at the bolted anchors atop Slapstick (about 50' lower). If you climb all the way to the pine tree you can make it down easily with two single rope raps.
content.protection: 3 bolts, FP, gear to 3", bolted anchor/rap
content.location:
This fun and highly overlooked route is located down and right from Slapstick, a prominent bolted arete, and immediately right of

Standup Flake

.
